title: The Fascinating Story of How the Electric Music Pioneer Delia Derbyshire Created the Original Doctor Who Theme (1963)
body:
in Music, Television | October 6th, 2025 Leave a Comment

Weâ€™ve focused a fair bit here on the work of Delia DerÂ­byshire, pioÂ­neerÂ­ing elecÂ­tronÂ­ic comÂ­posÂ­er of the mid-twenÂ­tiÂ­eth cenÂ­tuÂ­ryâ€”feaÂ­turÂ­ing two docÂ­uÂ­menÂ­taries on her and disÂ­cussing her role in almost creÂ­atÂ­ing an elecÂ­tronÂ­ic backÂ­ing track for Paul McCartneyâ€™s â€œYesÂ­terÂ­day.â€ Thereâ€™s good reaÂ­son to devote so much attenÂ­tion to her: Derbyshireâ€™s work with the BBCâ€™s RadioÂ­phonÂ­ic WorkÂ­shop laid the bedrock for a good deal of the sound design we hear on TV and radio today.

And, as we pointÂ­ed out preÂ­viÂ­ousÂ­ly, her elecÂ­tronÂ­ic music, recordÂ­ed under her own name and with the band White Noise, influÂ­enced â€œmost every curÂ­rent legÂ­end in the businessâ€”from Aphex Twin and the ChemÂ­iÂ­cal BrothÂ­ers to Paul HartÂ­noll of Orbital.â€

Yet for all her influÂ­ence among dance music comÂ­posers and sound effects wizÂ­ards, DerÂ­byshire and her music remain pretÂ­ty obscureâ€”that is except for one comÂ­poÂ­siÂ­tion, instantÂ­ly recÂ­ogÂ­nizÂ­able as the origÂ­iÂ­nal theme to the BBCâ€™s sci-fi hit DocÂ­tor Who (hear it at the top), â€œthe best-known work of a ragÂ­tag group of techÂ­niÂ­cians,â€ writes The Atlantic, â€œwho unwitÂ­tingÂ­ly helped shape the course of 20th-cenÂ­tuÂ­ry music.â€ WritÂ­ten by comÂ­posÂ­er Ron GrainÂ­er, the song was actuÂ­alÂ­ly brought into being by the RadioÂ­phonÂ­ic WorkÂ­shop, and by DerÂ­byshire espeÂ­cialÂ­ly. The stoÂ­ry of the DocÂ­tor Who themeâ€™s creÂ­ation is almost as interÂ­estÂ­ing as the tune itself, with its â€œswoopÂ­ing, hissÂ­ing and pulsÂ­ingâ€ that â€œmanÂ­ages to be at once hauntÂ­ing, goofy and etheÂ­reÂ­al.â€ Just above, you can see DerÂ­byshire and her assisÂ­tant Dick Mills tell it in brief.

What we learn from them is fasÂ­ciÂ­natÂ­ing, conÂ­sidÂ­erÂ­ing that comÂ­poÂ­siÂ­tions like this are now creÂ­atÂ­ed in powÂ­erÂ­ful comÂ­putÂ­er sysÂ­tems with dozens of sepÂ­aÂ­rate tracks and digÂ­iÂ­tal effects. The DocÂ­tor Who theme, on the othÂ­er hand, recordÂ­ed in 1963, was made even before basicÂ anaÂ­log synÂ­theÂ­sizÂ­ers came into use. â€œThere are no musiÂ­cians,â€ says Mills, â€œthere are no synÂ­theÂ­sizÂ­ers, and in those days, we didnâ€™t even have a 2â€‘track or a stereo machine, it was always mono.â€ (Despite popÂ­uÂ­lar misÂ­conÂ­cepÂ­tions, the theme does not feaÂ­ture a Theremin.) DerÂ­byshire conÂ­firms; each and every part of the song â€œwas conÂ­structÂ­ed on quarÂ­ter-inch mono tape,â€ she says, â€œinch by inch by inch,â€ using such recordÂ­ing techÂ­niques as â€œfilÂ­tered white noiseâ€ and someÂ­thing called a â€œwobÂ­buÂ­laÂ­tor.â€ How were all of these painstakÂ­ingÂ­ly conÂ­structÂ­ed indiÂ­vidÂ­ual parts comÂ­bined withÂ­out mulÂ­tiÂ­track techÂ­nolÂ­oÂ­gy? â€œWe creÂ­atÂ­ed three sepÂ­aÂ­rate tapes,â€ DerÂ­byshire explains, â€œput them onto three machines and stood next to them and said â€œReady, steady, go!â€ and pushed all the â€˜startâ€™ butÂ­tons at once. It seemed to work.â€

The theme came about when GrainÂ­er received a comÂ­misÂ­sion from the BBC after his well-received work on othÂ­er series. He â€œcomÂ­posed the theme on a sinÂ­gle sheet of A4 manÂ­uÂ­script,â€ writes Mark Ayres in an extenÂ­sive online hisÂ­toÂ­ry, â€œand sent it over from his home in PorÂ­tuÂ­gal, leavÂ­ing the WorkÂ­shop to get on with it.â€ Aware that the musique conÂ­crÃ¨te techÂ­niques DerÂ­byshire and her team used â€œwere very time-conÂ­sumÂ­ing, GrainÂ­er proÂ­vidÂ­ed a very simÂ­ple comÂ­poÂ­siÂ­tion, in essence just the famous bass line and a swoopÂ­ing melody,â€ as well as vagueÂ­ly evocaÂ­tive instrucÂ­tions for orchesÂ­traÂ­tion like â€œwind bubÂ­bleâ€ and â€œcloud.â€ Ayres writes, â€œTo an invenÂ­tive radioÂ­phonÂ­ic comÂ­posÂ­er such as Delia DerÂ­byshire, this was a gift.â€ Indeed â€œupon hearÂ­ing it,â€ The Atlantic notes, â€œa very impressed GrainÂ­er bareÂ­ly recÂ­ogÂ­nized it as his comÂ­poÂ­siÂ­tion. Due to BBC poliÂ­cies at the time, Grainerâ€”against his objectionsâ€”is still offiÂ­cialÂ­ly credÂ­itÂ­ed as the sole writer.â€ But the credÂ­it for this futurÂ­isÂ­tic workâ€”which sounds absoluteÂ­ly like nothÂ­ing else of the time and â€œwhich brought to a wide audiÂ­ence methÂ­ods once excluÂ­sive to the high modÂ­ernism of experÂ­iÂ­menÂ­tal compositionâ€â€”should equalÂ­ly go to DerÂ­byshire and her team. You can conÂ­trast that ahead-of-its-time origÂ­iÂ­nal theme with all of the iterÂ­aÂ­tions to folÂ­low in the video just above.

Note: An earÂ­liÂ­er verÂ­sion of this post appeared on our site in 2016.

Meet Four Women Who PioÂ­neered ElecÂ­tronÂ­ic Music: Daphne Oram, LauÂ­rie Spiegel, Ã‰liane Radigue & Pauline OlivÂ­eros

Josh Jones is a writer and musiÂ­cian based in Durham, NC.Â

title: A Complete Digitization of Leonardo Da Vinciâ€™s Codex Atlanticus, the Largest Collection of His Drawings & Writings
body:
No hisÂ­torÂ­iÂ­cal figÂ­ure betÂ­ter fits the defÂ­iÂ­nÂ­iÂ­tion of â€œRenaisÂ­sance manâ€ than LeonarÂ­do da VinÂ­ci, but that term has become so overused as to become misÂ­leadÂ­ing. We use it to express mild surÂ­prise that one perÂ­son could use both their left and right hemiÂ­spheres equalÂ­ly well. But in Leonardoâ€™s day, peoÂ­ple did not think of themÂ­selves as havÂ­ing two brains, and the worlds of art and sciÂ­ence were not so far apart as they are now.

That LeonarÂ­do was able to comÂ­bine fine arts and fine engiÂ­neerÂ­ing may not have been overÂ­ly surÂ­prisÂ­ing to his conÂ­temÂ­poÂ­raries, though he was an extraÂ­orÂ­diÂ­narÂ­iÂ­ly brilÂ­liant examÂ­ple of the pheÂ­nomÂ­eÂ­non. The more we learn about him, the more we see how closeÂ­ly relatÂ­ed the two purÂ­suits were in his mind.

He approached everyÂ­thing he did as a techÂ­niÂ­cian. The uncanÂ­ny effects he achieved in paintÂ­ing were the result, as in so much RenaisÂ­sance art, of mathÂ­eÂ­matÂ­iÂ­cal preÂ­ciÂ­sion, careÂ­ful study, and firstÂ­hand obserÂ­vaÂ­tion.

His artisÂ­tic projects were also experÂ­iÂ­ments. Some of them failed, as most experÂ­iÂ­ments do, and some he abanÂ­doned, as he did so many sciÂ­enÂ­tifÂ­ic projects. No matÂ­ter what, he nevÂ­er underÂ­took anyÂ­thing, whether mechanÂ­iÂ­cal, anatomÂ­iÂ­cal, or artisÂ­tic, withÂ­out careÂ­ful planÂ­ning and design, as his copiÂ­ous noteÂ­books tesÂ­tiÂ­fy. As more and more of those noteÂ­books have become availÂ­able online, both RenaisÂ­sance scholÂ­ars and laypeoÂ­ple alike have learned conÂ­sidÂ­erÂ­ably more about how Leonardoâ€™s mind worked.

First, there was the Codex ArunÂ­del. It is, writes Jonathan Jones at The Guardian, â€œthe livÂ­ing record of a uniÂ­verÂ­sal mindâ€â€”but also, specifÂ­iÂ­calÂ­ly, the mind of a â€œtechnophile.â€ Then, the VicÂ­toÂ­ria and Albert NationÂ­al Art Library announced the digÂ­iÂ­tiÂ­zaÂ­tion of Codex Forster, which conÂ­tains some of Leonardoâ€™s earÂ­liÂ­est noteÂ­books. Now The VisuÂ­al Agency has releasedÂ a comÂ­plete digÂ­iÂ­tiÂ­zaÂ­tion of Leonardoâ€™s Codex AtlantiÂ­cus, a huge colÂ­lecÂ­tion of the artist, engiÂ­neer, and inventorâ€™s fineÂ­ly-illusÂ­tratÂ­ed notes.

â€œNo othÂ­er colÂ­lecÂ­tion counts more origÂ­iÂ­nal papers writÂ­ten by LeonarÂ­do,â€ notes Google. The Codex AtlantiÂ­cus â€œconÂ­sists of 1119 papers, most of them drawn or writÂ­ten on both sides.â€ Its name has â€œnothÂ­ing to do with the Atlantic Ocean, or with some esoÂ­teric, mysÂ­teÂ­riÂ­ous conÂ­tent hidÂ­den in its pages.â€ The 12-volÂ­ume colÂ­lecÂ­tion acquired its title because the drawÂ­ings and writÂ­ings were bound with the same size paper that was used for makÂ­ing atlases. GathÂ­ered in the 16th cenÂ­tuÂ­ry by sculpÂ­tor PomÂ­peo Leoni, the papers descendÂ­ed from Leonardoâ€™s close stuÂ­dent GioÂ­van Francesco Melzi, who was entrustÂ­ed with them after his teacherâ€™s death.

The hisÂ­toÂ­ry of the Codex itself makes for a fasÂ­ciÂ­natÂ­ing narÂ­raÂ­tive, much of which you can learn at Googleâ€™s Ten Key Facts slideshow. The noteÂ­books span Leonardoâ€™s career, from 1478, when he was â€œstill workÂ­ing in his native TusÂ­cany, to 1519, when he died in France.â€ The colÂ­lecÂ­tion was takÂ­en from Milan by Napoleon and brought to France, where it remained in the LouÂ­vre until 1815, when the ConÂ­gress of VienÂ­na ruled that all artÂ­works stolen by the forÂ­mer EmperÂ­or be returned. (The emisÂ­sary tasked with returnÂ­ing the Codex could not deciÂ­pher Leonardoâ€™s mirÂ­ror writÂ­ing and took it for ChiÂ­nese.)

The Codex conÂ­tains not only engiÂ­neerÂ­ing diaÂ­grams, anatoÂ­my studÂ­ies, and artisÂ­tic sketchÂ­es, but also fables writÂ­ten by LeonarÂ­do, inspired by FloÂ­renÂ­tine litÂ­erÂ­aÂ­ture. And itÂ feaÂ­tures Leonardoâ€™s famed â€œCV,â€ a letÂ­ter he wrote to the Duke of Milan describÂ­ing in nine points his qualÂ­iÂ­fiÂ­caÂ­tions for the post of milÂ­iÂ­tary engiÂ­neer. In point four, he writes, â€œI still have very conÂ­veÂ­nient bombÂ­ing methÂ­ods that are easy to transÂ­port; they launch stones and simÂ­iÂ­lar such in a temÂ­pest full of smoke to frightÂ­en the eneÂ­my, causÂ­ing great damÂ­age and conÂ­fuÂ­sion.â€

As if in illusÂ­traÂ­tion, elseÂ­where in the Codex, the drawÂ­ing above appears, â€œone of the most celÂ­eÂ­bratÂ­edâ€ of the colÂ­lecÂ­tion.â€Â It was â€œshown to travÂ­elÂ­ing forÂ­eignÂ­ers visÂ­itÂ­ing the Ambrosiana [the BibÂ­lioteÂ­ca Ambrosiana in Milan, where the Codex resides] since the 18th cenÂ­tuÂ­ry, usuÂ­alÂ­ly arousÂ­ing much amazeÂ­ment.â€ It is still amazÂ­ing, espeÂ­cialÂ­ly if we conÂ­sidÂ­er the posÂ­siÂ­bilÂ­iÂ­ty that its artistry might have been someÂ­thing of a byprodÂ­uct for its creÂ­ator, whose priÂ­maÂ­ry motiÂ­vaÂ­tion seems to have been solvÂ­ing techÂ­niÂ­cal problemsâ€”in the most eleÂ­gant ways imagÂ­inÂ­able.

See theÂ comÂ­plete digÂ­iÂ­tiÂ­zaÂ­tion of Leonardoâ€™s Codex AtlantiÂ­cus here.

Note: An earÂ­liÂ­er verÂ­sion of this post appeared on our site in 2019.

LeonarÂ­do da Vinciâ€™s EarÂ­liÂ­est NoteÂ­books Now DigÂ­iÂ­tized and Made Free Online: Explore His IngeÂ­nious DrawÂ­ings, DiaÂ­grams, MirÂ­ror WritÂ­ing & More

How LeonarÂ­do da VinÂ­ci Drew an AccuÂ­rate SatelÂ­lite Map of an ItalÂ­ian City (1502)

LeonarÂ­do da Vinciâ€™s HandÂ­writÂ­ten Resume (CirÂ­ca 1482)

LeonarÂ­do Da Vinciâ€™s To-Do List from 1490: The Plan of a RenaisÂ­sance Man

Josh Jones is a writer and musiÂ­cian based in Durham, NC.Â

title: Meet Hyperallergicâ€™s New Editor-in-ChiefÂ
body:
Four weeks ago, I became a new American. It was a momentous finale to a quarter-century odyssey that started at the cusp of the millennium and ended just last month. The road here was anything but straight, twisting through bureaucratic brambles and detours. Yet, isnâ€™t every winding way toward belonging the true inheritance of wanderers at heart?

Today, I stand at another crossroads.Â 

When Veken and I launched Hyperallergic in 2009, our venture was fueled by a love of art writing and the stubborn belief that an independent voice could thrive without the largesse of the 1%. My resolve to amplify stories untold and to champion marginalized voices ensured that we made waves in a stagnant art media pool, one where wealthy patrons preferred comfort over candor. Veken, for his part, proved naysayers wrong: Readers will rally for independent art writing, for stories rooted in fact, heart, and public good.

Over 16 years, we became a home to over 2,500 voices while launching many into new fields. Together, we proved independence and criticality can flourish alongside a growing audience of readers invested in changing the landscape with thoughtful prose and electric ideas.

Our work seeded new conversations. In-depth stories about archaeology, memes, social justice, protest, once peripheral, are now mainstream. Our playful candor, once ours alone among major art publications, is echoed in corporate outfits today. Authors who hatched their visions with us went on to bigger books and bolder inquiries. Through it all, we have relished the journey â€” sometimes after meeting a deadline, sometimes in the quiet aftermath. We are immensely proud of our role in shifting the discourse around art and its social impact and roles. It was a lot of work, but we got here.

Making change in the field of contemporary art is never easy. When we began, we naÃ¯vely ignored the fieldâ€™s idiosyncrasies â€” those invisible hands that stifle true journalism, laud superficial change or reform, and sometimes threaten to sap the joy from artâ€™s urgent questions. But we persevered, cultivating a community of readers and writers who labor in and love the arts.

Now, another transition: Itâ€™s time for a new Editor-in-Chief.Â Welcome, Hakim Bishara.

A Palestinian writer, editor, curator, and artist, Hakim has authored some of the best reviews and opinions of the last few years, providing an unfiltered take on art that continued Hyperallergicâ€™s commitment and work. Since joining Hyperallergic in 2019, he has woven his global and local instincts into every story. As Staff Reporter, Senior Editor, and most recently Managing Editor, heâ€™s championed emerging and marginalized talent and encouraged us to look harder, dig deeper, and investigate issues we might have otherwise missed. His journalistic journey wound through international media, including contributions to BBC, Euronews, and more, touching on politics, art, and social change; his essays and criticism have appeared in +972 Magazine, the Financial Times, BOMB, Al Jazeera, and beyond. In the last few years, Hakim has penned powerful reviews of exhibitions by Jenny Holzer, Ai Weiwei, Caspar David Friedrich, and an essay on the â€œFabricated Crisis of Art Criticism,â€ which posited that â€œgood art criticism is the crisis.â€

Hakimâ€™s writing grapples with labor, funding, and representation, while maintaining a critical eye toward elitism and a heart for justice. He has received prestigious grants, holds an MFA in Art Writing from the School of Visual Arts, and studied law and international relations at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.

I have a great deal of faith that Hakim will usher Hyperallergic into new, uncharted territories â€” challenging our old assumptions, forging fresh paths. Entrusting someone with the top role has long been my dream; now realized, I do so with confidence and anticipation.

As for me: my role shifts to Editor-at-Large. My words, reviews, and reporting will continue on screens, in podcasts, and in more projects yet to come. But first, Iâ€™ll pause, as I step back a little to reflect on all weâ€™ve built. In learning what it means to be an American, I am learning too to be less editor and more writer. I hope you will welcome Hakim to the helm of the best independent art publication anywhere as we continue to change and evolve. Under his watchful eye, I know Hyperallergic is in good hands.

title: An Exhibition Axed Under Trumpâ€™s DEI Ban Finds a New Home
body:
One of the first exhibitions to be terminated as a result of Trumpâ€™s attacks on Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) has found a new home in Fairfax, Virginia. On Saturday, September 13, Before the Americas, initially slated for the Art Museum of the Americas in Washington, DC, officially opened its doors at the Gillespie Gallery at George Mason University School of Art. Featuring the work of 39 artists representing 17 countries, including Amy Sherald, Renee Stout, Alma Thomas, Elizabeth Catlett, and Alonzo Davis, the show explores ancestral memory, migration, and interconnectivity in African American, Afro-Latino, and Caribbean communities through mediums from sculpture to printmaking to book art.

Cheryl Edwards, the exhibitionâ€™s curator, told Hyperallergic she felt â€œrelieved and redeemedâ€ when the show opened for the public â€” â€œYou know, like Bob Marleyâ€™s Redemption Song,â€ she said.

The exhibition was set to open at the Art Museum of the Americas, part of the Organization of American States, on March 21, four years after it was first commissioned. In February, Edwards received a phone call informing her that the show had been terminated. The Trump administration had allegedly labeled it a â€œDEI program and eventâ€ and withdrawn funding for the show, which had been previously secured under the Biden administration.Â 

President Trump signed an executive order banning DEI initiatives, established to provide individuals from marginalized communities and lower socioeconomic backgrounds with equal opportunities in the workforce, on his first day in office.

Before the Americas was one of the earliest casualties in a series of art exhibitions and performances axed in the wake of the administrationâ€™s mandate. A second show at the Art Museum of the Americas, featuring LGBTQ+ artists, also lost its funding. When President Trump appointed himself as the Board Chair of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, a number of performances vanished from its programming, including the Gay Menâ€™s Chorus of Washingtonâ€™s Pride celebration concert and a performance of Eureka Day, a play centered around vaccine policy.

When the federal funding was suddenly cut, Edwards had to find a new, alternative way to fund the exhibition. She estimates there were â€œabout 50 or 60 donorsâ€ who allowed for the show to continue at a different location. â€œIt really brought us closer together as an art community,â€ Edwards said, â€œand it shows that we really understand the importance of having art and culture in our society, and that art transcends politics and orders.â€

When word got out that Before the Americas had been terminated, Donald Russell, director of Mason Exhibitions, which runs the Gillespie Gallery, immediately opened its doors for it. Russell and Edwards had previously worked together in a different capacity, exhibiting her work.Â He had also been involved in the early stages of the exhibition in a consulting role. â€œI was absolutely prepared to take it on,â€ Russell told Hyperallergic.

With bold color palettes and dynamic lines, the Afrocentric artworks represent the history of African-descendant artists. Thereâ€™s striking power in Lois Mailou Jonesâ€™s 1996 silkscreen print of three African dancers, and subtle strength in Elizabeth Catlettâ€™s â€œNiÃ±aâ€ (1957), the profile of a young girl.Â 

â€œThe history of African-descendant artists does not begin with slavery,â€ said Edwards. â€œThatâ€™s the whole point of this show.â€Â 

Before the Americas will be at Gillespie Gallery until November 15. After that, the exhibition will travel the area. In February, it is set to open at the University of Maryland Global Campus, where itâ€™ll be until May. Subsequent locations are yet to be announced.

Edwards recognizes the threats facing the cultural sector and underlines the importance of resilience. â€œBecause things are being erased,â€ she said, â€œI think as an artist, and as a cultural worker, it is our duty to create right now and document this moment in history.â€Â 

As for Before the Americas, Edwards has reconsidered its place in the current moment for the arts.Â 

â€œIâ€™m thinking of it as radical beauty at this point,â€ she said. â€œThereâ€™s no way that I can say personally I would want to live in a place without art and without culture that includes everyone that is multicultural.â€Â

title: NYC Artist and Educator Wins Zohran Mamdani Sticker Contest
body:
The feline residents of New York Cityâ€™s corner delis and convenience stores have long been beloved community icons, inspiring everything from popular Instagram and Tiktok accounts to childrenâ€™s books and magazine covers. Now, the bodega cat is at the forefront of Democratic Socialist Zohran Mamdaniâ€™s mayoral campaign thanks to a sticker contest aimed at boosting voter registration.

Hundreds of artists submitted designs to Mamdaniâ€™s 36-hour â€œI Registered to Vote for Zohranâ€ sticker contest. They focused on quintessential New York City imagery like public buses, street signs, subways, and pigeons that were then voted on by thousands of users online.

On Monday, September 29, Mamdani announced the winner on Instagram: a glowing red, blue, and gold watercolor illustration depicting a bodega storefront, created by arts educator and freelance illustrator Nishan Patel. Lounging window-side, a pink furry feline is bathed in the warm glow of the small businessâ€™s interior, a tender homage to the neighborhood delis and its workers that make NYC the unique home that it is.

â€œIt was a very close race with tons of amazing submissions,â€ said Mamdaniâ€™s post, noting that the sticker will be available at Mamdani campaign events throughout the month of October.

The custom sticker spotlight on bodega cats was praised by users online, including the popular Cats for Zohran Instagram account, which had been promoting both Patelâ€™s submission and another feline-focused sticker. â€œBIG PURR ENERGY ğŸ¾,â€ Cats for Zohran commented.

Today, Mamdani featured the design in a promotional voter registration video parodying the iconic Mean Girls (2004) â€œOctober 3â€ scene.

With Election Day just one month away, this week proved to be a pivotal time for the NYCâ€™s mayoral race. New York Mayor Eric Adams announced that he had withdrawn his third-party bid for re-election, reducing the race to three candidates: the young Democrat primary winner Mamdani, disgraced former Governor Andrew Cuomo, and Republican Curtis Sliwa. Results from a New York Times/Siena poll released today show that Mamdani is currently maintaining a strong lead in the race following Adamsâ€™s exit.

Mamdaniâ€™s campaign, which is rooted in door-to-door canvassing efforts and extensive social media outreach, has notably mobilized young people across the city, including those who are not even yet eligible to vote â€” such as Isla Dalisay-Hockett, the 14-year-old artist behind a popular pigeon design submission for the sticker contest.

Dalisay-Hockett told Hyperallergic that she came up with her drawing while she was on the subway.

â€œI really like the winning sticker,â€ Dalisay-Hockett said, noting that it â€œmatchesâ€ the campaignâ€™s focus on small businesses, which Mamdani has proposed supporting by cutting business fines in half, simplifying online applications, and boosting funding for mom-and-pop shops.

â€Šâ€His campaign is one of the ones where people are very excited,â€ Dalisay-Hockett said.

â€œHeâ€™s young, heâ€™s new to the political landscape, and his wife is a cool artist,â€ she continued, referring to Syrian, Brooklyn-based illustrator and animator Rama Duwaji. â€œThereâ€™s so much just to be excited about in his campaign, and I think itâ€™s really cool.â€

Maya Pontone (she/her) is a Staff News Writer at Hyperallergic. Originally from northern New Jersey, she currently resides in Brooklyn, where she covers daily news affecting the arts and culture, both... More by Maya Pontone

title: Lygia Pape Wants You to Participate
body:
PARIS â€”Â This year, Paris didnâ€™t slip back intoÂ la rentrÃ©e, that annual return from summer break to regular life,Â so much as lurch into it. Whatâ€™s usually a seasonal shrug â€” crowded trains, humming cafÃ©s, full schools â€” has become a barometer of national discontent. Five prime ministers in two years, a fragmented National Assembly, and the steady rise of Marine Le Penâ€™s far right have left France polarized to the point of vertigo. Transport shutdowns, student blockades, and museum strikes have turned back-to-school rhythms into acts of protest.

On a balmy September afternoon, just two days after large-scale protests opposing the austerity measures proposed by Prime Minister FranÃ§ois Bayrouâ€™s government took place, volunteers recruited via an open call of â€œeveryone from 7 to 99â€ reenacted â€œDivisorâ€ (1968), one of late Brazilian avant-garde artistÂ Lygia Papeâ€™s most iconic participatory performances, on the streets of Paris. The event opened the Festival dâ€™Automne â€” a three-month celebration of dance, theater, music, performance, and visual art â€” and marked the inauguration ofÂ Lygia Pape: Weaving Space, the artistâ€™s first solo exhibition in France at the Bourse de Commerceâ€“Pinault Collection.

I arrived an hour before the performance and drifted through the rooms. The show is small but tightly curated, a compressed burst of some of Papeâ€™s most emblematic works that showcases the breadth of her experimental practice across media. In one gallery, the short filmÂ â€œO ovoâ€Â (The Egg, 1967) plays. In it, Pape presses against the taut skin of a white cube on a beach, tears through, and crawls into the sand â€” geometry giving way to flesh. Across the room, a panoramic projection ofÂ â€œDivisor,â€ performedÂ at Rio de Janeiroâ€™s Museu de Arte Moderna in 2010, spans the wall. In a plexiglass case sitsÂ â€œLivro da CriaÃ§Ã£oâ€Â (Book of Creation, 1959â€“60), a defining piece of Papeâ€™s Neo-Concrete period. It takes the form of 16 artist books that unfold pop-up sculptural forms such as triangles flaring into fire, a fan unfurling a wheel, and a red disc becoming a clock â€”Â a cosmos animated by our hands.Â 

On display, too, is the monumentalÂ â€œLivro Noite e Dia IIIâ€Â (Book of Night and Day III, 1963â€“76), comprising 365 carved wooden units arranged into a shifting field of black, white, and gray that maps the daily swing between light and dark across a year. And a gorgeous grouping of theÂ Tecelares, woodcut prints she made throughout the 1950s depicting labyrinthine geometric motifs, works as an anteroom for what is undoubtedly the showstopper: the dazzlingÂ â€œTtÃ©ia 1, Câ€Â (2001â€“7), in which hundreds of copper wires stretch across a pitch-dark room lit by spotlights, an immersive sensory experience that itself changes with our movements.

Back on the street,Â â€œDivisorâ€Â expands that same participatory principle to a collective scale. More than 100 participants ducked under a long white sheet, their heads popping through slits, as they spilled out from the rear of La Bourseâ€™s imposing neoclassical facade and glided like a giant white amoeba across the esplanade toward La CanopÃ©e des Halles. Phones held high, some filmed themselves and their fellow travellers. The mood was upbeat, buoyant; small children at the front gave the procession a playful air.

Walking alongside this strange, lovely spectacle, it struck me thatÂ â€œDivisorâ€Â endures because it makes us feel collectivity as a physical condition rather than a concept â€”Â the brush of hair, the weight of fabric, the awkward give-and-take with strangers, freedom tested in public space. Yet this reenactment carries a trace of its own scaffolding â€” the museum, social media, the logic of the festival. In that sense, the ParisÂ edition of â€œDivisorâ€Â felt less like a time capsule than a pulsing diagnostic: a fleeting republic stitched from cloth, bodies, and hashtags.

Lygia Pape: Weaving Space continues at Bourse de Commerce â€“ Pinault Collection (2 Rue de Viarmes, Paris, France) through January 26, 2026. The exhibition was curated by Emma Lavigne with Alexandra Bordes.

title: Almine Rech Closes London Gallery After More Than a Decade
description: Almine Rech will close its gallery in Londonâ€™s Mayfair district, Melani
body:
Almine Rech will close its gallery in Londonâ€™s Mayfair district, Melanie Gerlis reported in the Art Newspaper on Friday. The space had been open for more than a decade, mounting shows for artists such as Javier Calleja, Chloe Wise, Jeff Koons, Esther Mahlangu, and many more.

Dealer Almine Rech, who founded her gallery in 1997 in Paris, told Gerlis that London remains â€œimportantâ€ to her operation and that she â€œwill open somethingâ€ in the city in the future, without providing further specifics.

Gerlis also reported that Almine Rechâ€™s London branch was put into liquidation. She referred to Companies House filings that suggest the gallery has a Â£6.3 million deficit. Rech said she did not owe money to artists, workers, or suppliers, and that the liquidation filing was â€œa technical step to restructure a lease that no longer aligned with our plans.â€

Related Articles

Rechâ€™s gallery will continue to operate the remaining eight locations, two of which are sited in Paris. The remaining six are spread across New York, Brussels, Shanghai, Monaco, and Gstaad.

Her gallery opened in London in 2014 on Savile Row before moving two years later to Grosvenor Hill, placing Almine Rech next door to Gagosian, which continues to operate its space there. (Gagosian, for its part, closed another of its London galleries in 2023 after 19 years.)

Earlier this year, dealer Almine Rech told ARTnews that she had lost some of her London collectors after new tax rules were instituted in the UK. â€œOnce people go away and settle somewhere else, usually they donâ€™t come backâ€”when money leaves a place, it is not good,â€ she said. She also added, â€œI believe the UK has a strong capacity to react.â€

To what extent Brexit may have played a role in Rechâ€™s decision was unclear based on Gerlisâ€™s report. But in 2023, some London dealers told ARTnews that the British art market remained strong, even as the one in France grows in prominence.

The last exhibition staged at its London gallery, a Gregor Hildebrandt solo show, closed on July 26.
